text: so why should we fear apis well I think
we should fear them and love them but
you know I think right now people are
not really talking about apis that much
so there should just be more discussion
but here's what's happening in the last
10 years the rise of apis has meant that
it's easier to build software than ever
before uh an example I have is I was
judging a university hackathon a few
years ago and I myself had gone to
hackathons when I was a student and back
then we were like oh my gosh look it's
the end of the weekend and our Lego
robot can now bang into the side of the
wall great um you know that's that's
about how much you could achieve over
over the course of a hackathon and uh
the students that I was judging they
were you know sending text messages
based on your bank account they were
doing things that based on where you
were geographically playing different
kinds of music and it all came down to
apis it was you know they're using the
Capital One API the Google Maps API the
twillo API the building blocks that the
apis provided was what made all of this
possible and so the the trend of apis
taking everything over has been
incredible people can build way more
quickly than before uh people aren't
building as much inhouse and you know
you can you can spin up a whole
functioning company in a week now
because of everything that's available
out there and so that part people have
been talking about people say oh this is
really cool you know etc etc API
companies are getting a lot of funding
but the flip side is that this is now a
huge pile of software that is not uh
known end to end to any individual user
and all of the tooling that most
developers are using these days are
built for software that a developer has
built to first party and to end and so
if you think about what people think
about when they uh think developer tools
it's you know what's in my IDE what's in
how do I do my integration tests how do
I do my endtoend test what's my build
deploy release process like there is
some stuff people use for monitoring and
observability but often it's you know
did I log everything I intended to log
because this is my system and I'm
optimizing 99th percentile tail latency
and so what I believe is missing is a
space of tools that accommodate the
reality that people are building
software systems that they don't have
full control over they're building
software systems that are evolving in
ways that they're not determining
themselves and they shouldn't be
expected to be monitoring these systems
end to endend or know what it means to
get low-level logs on parts of these
systems and so um in in terms of the
questions that I said people should
should be afraid of what is my software
doing is it doing what I'm supposed to
do we should be really afraid of apis
because we're not we're not able to
answer those questions
anymore
